Kyle et al-
	I have to say I liked this considerably better than the earlier 
excerpt (apologies to Lillith). This is my favorite area of Japanese 
history so I may be too harsh a critic.  "Restaurant", "waitress" and 
"bathroom" are all too modern and invoke the "groan" and  catapult the 
reader back into his world rather than keep him in yours. "Public 
House", "Tea room" or even "eatery" might work better, as would 
"servant-girl" and "outhouse" (privy). If it is 1854 then the language 
you use should invoke the 1850's, since we are close enough in time 
that most readers know what it should sound like (as opposed to the 
1550"s).
	 A single sailor strolls into a bar? All joking aside, in 1854 it is 
unlikely that Commodore Perry would have allowed any of the men of his 
command this kind of casual contact. Servant girls didn't hang around 
the table and "unn" was likely all the thanks she expected to receive. 
Domo Arigato-doitashimashite are again too modern, and jolt the reader 
out of the story. I think a samurai of these times would not call 
himself a "samurai" but rather "Bushi", if he has a good command of 
English then "warrior." However if he is giving Japanese lessons he 
should say "Bakufu",  I do not think he would have command of words 
like "Shogunate" which is afterall an English word.
	Mono Kenshu? Okinawans have funky names true, but farming samurai from 
Okinawa? Satsuma. Yes, I don't buy Okinawa. Josiah Louis, Joseph Louis, 
Jebediah Louis I could accept, "Joe" again sounds too modern. I also 
wonder how open-minded a working class white male from the American 
South of the 1850's might be toward Asians and their culture. If he 
were black he wouldn't be walking around with an interpreter and if he 
were important enough to be granted an interpreter he would likely not 
be strolling into a pub. And what about the interpreter!?! What does he 
interpret? When the Samurai speaks, is it his English we hear or is 
that the interpreter?
	I know I am picking nits here, so don't take me too seriously. Alot of 
my questions/concerns could easily be answered by the tale that is 
about to unfold. Tom Cruise movies aside this is certainly a period and 
place in history that is ripe for literary and theatrical dramatization 
and I for one am all for it.
-t

PS- I feel that the US was looking to beat the Europeans to Pacific 
Whaling to replace that lost in the Atlantic which was "overfished", 
coaling stations in Japan were vital to that effort, "trade and amity" 
were the sugar-coating used to sell the idea of open ports to Japan...
